Repeat blood cultures have all been negative for recurrent bacteremia given recent admission for strep bacteremia. TEE showed a stable TV mass consistent with pacemaker lead extraction. MRI of the whole spine was negative for osteomyelitis. Given no evidence of recurrent infection, all antibiotics were stopped. Fevers did not return and the patient was discharged to rehab given this was a likely viral infection. ACUTE ISSUES: #Fever #H/o strep bacteremia The patient had a recent admission from for pacemaker extraction in the setting of strep sanguinis bacteremia. The pacemaker was removed with no complication and last positive culture was on . Given recent dental procedure, dentistry evaluated the patient, but did not think this was the cause of his bacteremia. TEE at the time showed a TV mass on , but this is likely due to pacemaker extraction. PPM was reimplanted on and discharged on IV ceftriaxone 2g daily. The patient represented with AMS concerning for recurrent bacteremia, but blood cultures were all negative. ID was consulted and recommend repeat TEE which showed stable TV mass consistent with PPM extraction per EP. MRI spine showed no evidence of osteomyelitis. Discussion was had regarding need for cardiac CT to evaluate for abscess but this was deferred given contrast load. PET-CT was considered to evaluate for infection but given defervescence of fevers this was deferred. CRP remained elevated, but given clinical improvement no additional imaging was done. Vancomycin and ceftriaxone were discontinued early on prior to full 6 week course planned for presumed endocarditis which was and patient's fevers did not recur (per infectious disease). The leading thought remains fevers were from a viral illness. on CKD His Cr was stably elevated during last hospitalization (2.5-3.1), which may represent new baseline, and was 3.2 on admission. He was given fluid resuscitation early in the admission, developed crackles, elevated right-sided pressures noted on TTE, therefore a component of cardiorenal was considered. He was diuresed and developed a worsening consistent with ATN. His diuretic was held and ATN improved. Cr stabilized at 2.5 and Torsemide was restarted. #Chronic HFpEF EF 65%. His discharge weight from was 92.6 kg (204.14 lb). Admission weight 93.5 kg (206.13 lb). He received fluids early in the admission for presumed sepsis, became overloaded and was hemodynamically stable so was diuresed. Metoprolol was decreased given borderline blood pressure. Cr on discharge 2.5. Weight on discharge 100.8kg and 222.22lbs but this was a bed weight. #Macrocytic anemia: #Thrombocytopenia: Hgb 8.6 at last discharge, 8.3 on admission. Likely anemia of inflammation iso infection vs chronic back pain and CKD. Differential for macrocytic anemia may also include MDS given some degree of thrombocytopenia and increased MCV. Less likely hemolysis with normal AST and inappropriately low retics. This was stable on discharge. #Altered mental status #Toxic metabolic encephalopathy Presented with new onset inattention, disorientation. Likely due to systemic infection, renal failure, increased accumulation of gabapentin and Ativan with reduced renal function, perhaps cephalosporin neurotoxicity (though ceftriaxone not a big offender). NCHCT neg, non focal neuro exam. Mental status improved throughout hospital course. #Acute on chronic "back" pain in R posterior hip #History of spinal stenosis s/p surgery He reported pain in his right lower back, which appeared to be the pelvis with pain radiating down his right leg and subjective numbness of the right foot that began a few days after having a fall on hitting his hip and acutely worsened in the past week after being hospitalized and in bed. Given fever, and c/f bacteremia, osteo was considered. MRI showed evidence of cord compression, but in the absence of new neurologic findings, the patient will follow up with neurosurgery as an option for further options (this was discussed with patient's neurosurgeon). Physical therapy recommended rehab. #Rash: Patient developed an erythematous rash on his back with sloughing of his skin concerning for contact dermatitis from the sheets and moisture from sweat. This had improvement with antifungal powder and keeping the area open to air. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or wheelchair. Discharge Instructions: Dear Mr. , It was a privilege caring for you at . WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL? You were transferred from due to confusion, fevers, and concern you may have a bloodstream infection with possible infection in your pacemaker or aortic valve replacement. WHAT HAPPENED TO ME IN THE HOSPITAL? We did a full evaluation for infection including blood cultures, MRI of the spine, CT scan of the chest and transesophageal echocardiogram. These were all negative for infection. The infectious disease team, electrophysiology specialists and cardiologists worked with us and did not identify a cause for your fevers. The most likely cause of the fevers were from a virus. You kidneys suffered some injury so the nephrology team was consulted and recommended holding your Torsemide. Your kidneys eventually recovered back to its baseline and your Torsemide was restarted. Your antibiotics were held and no additional fevers developed and then discontinued. You had fluid removed with diuretics. Your blood pressure medications were adjusted given lower blood pressures. WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL? Please continue to check for fevers at rehab. Monitor your weights and call your doctor if your week increases >3lbs in a day or >5lbs in a week. Continue to take all your medicines and keep your appointments. We wish you the best. Sincerely, Your Team Followup Instructions:
